_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Deport Farm Supply has submitted this electronic RPM in compliance with the provision of the Clean Air Act 112(r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CPR Part 68.  Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR Part 1910.119 are not applicable to operations at this facility becuase the facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Deport Farm Supply's ammonia tank located approximately 0.8 miles SE of Deport off U.S. Highway 287.  (Please note that the ammonia tank is located just across the Lamar County line in Red River County whereas the main part of the facility is located on the eastern edge of Lamar County.)  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Deport Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Deport Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.

FACILITY

Helen Chemical Company engages in the formulation, distribution, and sale of chemicals to customers, most of whom use Helena's products to support agricultural operations.  The Deport Farm Supply is a retail agricultural chemical company that operates anhydrous ammonia storage tanks and sells Helena's ammonia to end customers.  Helena owns the ammonia up to the point of sale.  The actual ammonia operations at the Deport Facility are owned and managed by Deport Farm Supply.  Anhydrous ammonia processes at this location include storage, loading, and unloading.  Loading operations occur from trucks to storage tanks, and from storage tanks to end use processes.  End use processes may include fertilizer formulation and nurse tank transportation and operation.  

OFF-SITE CONSE

QUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst case and alternative consequence analyses were completed for the ammonia storage process.  The worst-case scenario release for the Deport Facility assumed that all 56,078 lbs of ammonia in the largest single storage tank were released.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at ground level.  The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint was 2.4 miles.  

The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes a violent rupture of a 3-inch line caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer line during a major loading or unloading operation.  Although this event is classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (rail guards, check valves) and operating procedures that Helena uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint in the alternative scenario was 0.40 miles.

Both the worst case and the alternative scenario are overly conservative because a 10-minute release is unlikely to occur since the check valves on the system should close immediately upon increased flow resulting from the severed transfer line.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Deport Facility complies with U.S. EPA's accidental release prevention rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  The Deport Facility provides safety information relevant to the on-site ammonia processes including MSDS documentation, storage and process limits, equipment specifications, and relevant codes and standards.  The Deport Facility has conducted a hazard review to ensure that potential safety problems are identified and addressed.  The Deport Facility has developed standard and consistent operating procedures that all employees follow when working with ammonia.  The Deport Facility ensures that all of its employees

working with or around ammonia participate in a training program.  The training program teaches employees how to avoid and respond to accidents.  Helena Chemical Company has also established integrated operation and maintenance procedures, inspection requirements and schedules, compliance audits, and incident investigation procedures. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Deport Farm Supply is a nonresponding facility.  Deport has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The operation of ammonia storage at the Deport Facility in the past five years has not resulted in any on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

CONCLUSION

The Risk Management Plan Implemented by Deport Farm Supply complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r).  The RMP will be updated as the Deport Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes.  The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the local fire department and Lamar County LEPC.

NOTE:  Sections 4,5, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Deport Facility.
